name: TheAtlantic
text: The first time Donald Trump ever made news involved accusations of bigotry against him. He has stuck with a winning formula. An oral history of key moments from Trump's public life, by @grahamdavida, @AdrienneNGreen, @ParkerTRichards, and Cullen Murphy: https://t.co/UNOhPTeuWh

name: TheAtlantic
text: Listen: @JamesFallows joins the "Social Distance" podcast to give @katlwells and @jameshamblin some historical perspective. https://t.co/8H1PcDMO8k

name: TheAtlantic
text: Listen: On the "Social Distance" podcast, @jameshamblin explains the difference between good cleaning and bad cleaning. https://t.co/qQxPmC7qYF

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @AdrienneLaF: “We can learn from these dreadful days that stupidity and injustice are lethal; that, in a democracy, being a citizen is essential work; that the alternative to solidarity is death.” https://t.co/BMKp23SZJb

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @AdrienneLaF: “The mission of the police is to protect and serve. But the premise of the soldier is to engage the enemy in close combat and destroy them. When you blur those lines together… It’s an absolute breakdown of civil society.” https://t.co/yQpX5xP4Nj

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @JohnGHendy: "The police and the U.S. military are separate institutions because policing a community and fighting a war are supposed to be separate jobs." https://t.co/X9j0VkKTrw via @NickBaumann

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @YAppelbaum: "He has purposefully inflamed America’s divisions. He has set himself against the American idea, the principle that all of us—of every race, gender, and creed—are created equal.” https://t.co/s9Y6UMQVCn

name: TheAtlantic
text: "Perhaps it was inevitable that officials would turn to military language as demonstrations spread across the country this week. In cities large and small, police departments are now outfitted like military units," @nickbaumann writes: https://t.co/nYqQ2m2v50

name: TheAtlantic
text: "I don’t see how anyone could remain in that position, knee driven into a by-now-inert mass of humanity, unless he was at best totally indifferent to the person’s survival," @gcaw writes: https://t.co/ktRwItMhDt

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @AdrienneLaF: "You could call birtherism a conspiracy theory, sure. But in 2020... it could be more accurately described as the governing ideology of the United States." https://t.co/tpYVTZHK7o
